div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: From the Valley.
div3.p:
The news from the Valley will prove to be of little interest to those who are not personally connected with this beautiful section of our State.
The protracted inclemency of the weather, caused by the deep snows, has successfully closed all offensive operations for the present.
But Milroy, regardless of this, is actively engaged.
He seems to have anticipated the raising of a negro army.
He is thoroughly scouring the Lower Valley.
Servants are persuaded off, and in many instances forced to leave their homes.
His officers are supplying themselves with waiters.
An officer who accompanied a flag of truce to Winchester reports the house occupied by Milroy himself to be ornamented with bright mulatto boys and girls.
He at first appeared to be dissatisfied with the result of his operations, and on two different occasions has been reinforced by cavalry.
Now we may expect the contrabands to be carried off by the wholesale.
We are glad to say that he is not arresting many citizens, although they are firm in their loyalty.
A few days since a Yankee upstart summoned an aged civilian to appear before him to furnish some information.
When duly arraigned, the Yankee began:
Do you know of any one who has furnished supplies to the rebels?
Old Man — I believe I do.
Yank — Who was it?
Answer.--General Banks.

Yank.--Sergeant, take him to the guard house.
Wait a while Now, old white headed rebel, mind whose presence you are in, and answer correctly.
Do you know any one who has been passing through our lines and back again to the rebels, carrying information?
Ans.--Yes, sir, I do.
Yank.--Who was it?
Aus.--General J. E. B. Stuart.
Yank.--Sergeant, take him to the guard-house.

Milroy's force is divided into three parts, each division being composed of near three thousand men. They are stationed at Winchester, Martinsburg, and Harper's Ferry.--His cavalry is scattered over the Lower Valley.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad furnishes his supplies.
They are hauled from Martinsburg to Winchester in trains comprising fifty wagons each, under charge of a small guard.
Desertions from the Federal army are becoming quite numerous; but the manner in which the railroad is guarded, (it being so complete,) forces them to take a circuitous route to escape.

Northern papers, of the 7th, afford no confirmation of the capture of the Florida or of its destruction.
A description of the repulse of rebel troops at Fort Donelson is all that is of importance.
For the facts given you, as well as myself, are indebted to

div3.head: Rye coffee — its Dangers.
div3.p:
A case of some interest to the drinkers of "rye" coffee has occurred in Brooklyn, N. Y. Several members of a family there were seriously affected by poison, alleged to have been contained in the coffee they drank.
An examination was made by the Health.
Officer of Brooklyn, who discovered that the sickness was caused by the continued use of coffee made by rye, and he was confirmed in his opinion by making experiments upon a dog. He therefore ordered the police to seize the packages on sale in the store from which the family alluded to had procured the coffee.
The following is the statement of the Health Officer in regard to the matter:

div4.head: Health Department,
div4.p:
On the 1st inst, Dr. M. Palmedo, of this city, reported that the entire family and the servant of a German merchant had for some time previously, and still suffered from the effects of vegetable poison, alleged to have been taken with their food.
I entered immediately upon the investigation of the case.
I found Mr. George C. Croft, his wife, two of his daughters, and one son, more or less under the influence of the supposed poison, the rest of the family being convalescent.
The servant had been removed to other quarters.

One of the young ladies was very sick; her face was bloated and disfigured like the dropsy; her eyelids were greatly distended, and could scarcely be opened; her eyeballs were bloodshot, and the pupils considerably dilated; she was then under violent fever, and very restless; she complained of headache and great dizziness; she was tortured by frightful dreams, and became at times delirious; besides this there was great pain in the back and extremities, the latter were moreover benumbed; she was very weak.
Learning that every member of the family had been thus affected, I could not hesitate in lending my official assistance in the discovery of the alleged poisonous cause.
Dr. Palmedo had already instituted the most searching inquiry, and at last has fixed his suspicious upon the so-called rye coffee, which the family had made use of for the last three or four weeks. After due deliberation on all the attending circumstances I could not help sharing in the suspicion, as no other cause could be assigned.

Ascertaining the places where the suspected articles had been bought.
I possessed myself of some samples, suspended the further sale of said articles at those places until its composition and effects could be fully examined into.
Chemical analysis and microscopical examinations being utterly impracticable, I resorted to experiments upon dogs.
In preparing a strong decoction of the sample, I noticed its strong, disagreeable, and nauseating flavor, very similar to that emanating from a decoction of ergot, yet stronger in the former.
The animal exhibited great restlessness and weakness; his movements and position were infirm; his pulse rose within an hour from 100 to 160, and even, for a short time, to 172 per minute; pupils became dilated; he was evidently sick at the stomach; very thirty.
It seemed to be conclusive that the samples used for the experiment contained noxious ingredients of a poisonous character.
The case of Mr. Croft's family is not a solitary one.
I had become cognizant of numerous instances in which the rye coffee had the same or similar effects, and such complaints had been made at the store from which the samples had been purchased.
I have therefore, considered myself justified in condemning the stock of the article, and have ordered its destruction.

Nobody should be surprised at the obnoxious effects of rye coffee, for with the rye itself grow ergot and other poisonous plants, and unless their seed be carefully separated from rye, poisoning is inevitable.
Pure rye is certainly a cheap and innocent substitute for coffee — the adulterations alone are to be feared in the article.
I hope this disclosure will teach manufacturers of the article to be more careful in the selection of the new material, otherwise the public will protect itself more effectually.

div3.head: Strange and terrible epidemic in the Northwest.
div3.p:
--The Northern papers tell of a strange and terrible epidemic that has broken out in Indians, completely baffling all efforts of the local physicians, and carrying off every patient in a few hours.
A paper thus describes the symptoms and progress of the disease:

There are no symptoms indicating its approach.
The patient is attacked with a chill, and thinks he has an attack of the ague; but as soon as the chill is over the patient sinks into a stupor, from which he rarely revives.--The muscles are rigid; the pupil of the eye is insensible to either light or touch; the surface of the body is extremely tender and sensitive; the head is drawn back; the jaws are fixed, and the breath is drawn forcibly, with a hissing sound, as if by great effort, through the closed teeth; the patient is blind and deaf.

In children the stupor is very liable to be broken by frequent convulsions.
During the stupor large black spots (many of them raised up like blisters) appear on the surface of the body and limbs, the patient usually dying in from two to four hours. In some rate cases the patient lingers along for days, in a species of low typhoid fever, accompanied by blindness, deafness, paralysis of the extremities, &c. In some cases the partient revives from the stupor, feeling so well as believe himself convalescent; but, in the course of an hour or two, is seized with a terrible delirium, terminating in come (a stupor) and death.
This disease leaves the patient in a typhoid fever, and very low, and liable to less of sight or hearing, and to paralysis, upon recovery.

div3.head: Letter from Governor Letcher to Lincoln.
div3.p:
A brief notice has been made of the letter addressed by the Governor of Virginia to Lincoln, on the subject of prisoners unjustly held by the United States Government and denied the right of exchange.
Our crowded columns have, until to-day, prevented the publication of this document, which belongs to the history of the war. After detailing the facts of Virginia's withdrawal from the United States and joining the Southern Confederacy, the Governor continues:

In the prosecution of this purpose, Colonel Richard Thomas Zarvona, an officer, with others under his command, with the authority and by express orders from the Executive of this State, planned and executed an expedition by which the steamer St. Nicholas, and other vessels belonging to the marine of the United States, were captured and brought as prizes into the waters of this State.
In a subsequent expedition, undertaken under the same authority, and, while bearing on his person a commission from the Governor of this State, appointing him a Colonel of volunteers, and with orders of a warlike character, he was arrested by the police on board the steamer Mary Washington, on her trip to Baltimore, and carried a prisoner to Fort McHenry.--From thence he has been removed, and is now confined at Fort Lafayette, as a felon, in a dungeon, and subjected to the greatest inhumanity.

That he was, under these circumstances, rightfully a prisoner of war is not denied, and that he might be held as such until exchanged under some cartel for the purpose, I do not controvert.
He had been known to be in hostility to the Government to the United States, and was liable, therefore, to be captured wherever found.
But he was not, in any sense, to be regarded as a felon, holding as he did the military commission of the State of Virginia, and in the execution of her military and naval orders.

If he was regarded in any other light than as a Colonel in the service of the State, then was he, in the language of the Constitution of the United States, entitled to a speedy and a public trial by an impartial jury of the State and district wherein the crime [shall have] had been committed, which district [shall] should have been previously ascertained by law, and to be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation; to be confronted with the witnesses against him; to have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his favor, and to have the assistance of counsel for his defence.
Notwithstanding this express clause, he has now been confined for eighteen months, and not one of the provisions contained in it has been attempted to be complied with.

The only cause that I have seen assigned for his incarceration was announced in a paper printed in the city of Baltimore on the 9th of July, 1861, immediately after his arrest, in which it is stated, "that Mr. Richard Thomas, and five or six other persons, were arrested on board the steamer Mary Washington, as she was coming up the bay yesterday.
The charge against them, we believe, was that they were concerned in the seizure of the St. Nicholas a few days since.
The party were coming up to the city as passengers, when they were pointed out by two spies on board the boat, and, as she reached the wharf at Fort McHenry, the boat rounded to, and they were delivered up to the officer in command." If his offence was the seizure of the St. Nicholas, that seizure was accomplished by a justifiable stratagem by naval and military officers of this State, in company with Col Zarvona, and with a design to carry out a bolder and more daring military and naval enterprise, the success of which would have been beyond doubt, if Virginia's action had not been thwarted by circumstances beyond her control.
When the St. Nicholas was taken, Col. Zarvona was an officer appointed by and in the service of Virginia, and was in flagrante bello engaged in a hostile act, and entitled to be considered, if taken, as a prisoner of war, and if taken afterwards for the offence, then committed, he could only be so considered and so treated.

Under the cartel for the exchange of prisoners, entered into between the Governments of the United States and the Confederate States, all prisoners of war were to be exchanged upon certain agreed terms.
Why Col. Zarvona has not been exchanged under this agreement it is for the Government of the United States to explain.
Why he has been subjected to indignities that no other prisoner have been compelled to undergo, is not for me to consider.
It is sufficient for the Executive of this State to be apprised of the fact, to induce him, for the sake of humanity and for the sake of the usages of civilized nations, to ask that such severities should not be practiced upon an officer in the service of this State for his obedience to orders emanating from her authority.
It is proper under all the circumstances of this case, that I should inform you distinctly of the course I have taken and the policy I intend to pursue.

Independent of the forces which have been contributed by this State to the armies of the Confederate States, Virginia has a force of her own operating under command of Major-Gen. John B. Floyd, by whom there have been captured two hundred and one prisoners, most of whom have been brought to the city of Richmond for safe custody.

From these prisoners I have taken two of the officers belonging to the fourth regiment of troops under the usurped Government of Virginia, to wit: Captain Thomas Damron and Lieutenant Wilson Damron, and have ordered them to be imprisoned in the Penitentiary of this State, and to be kept in solitary confinement; and I have further ordered that the following privates, to wit: John W. Howe, Isaac Goble, and David V. Auxier, who belonged to the 39th Kentucky regiment; and Samuel Pack, also from Kentucky, and William S. Dills, from Ohio, each of the 5th Virginia regiment, under the usurped Government to be also kept in the Penitentiary in solitary confinement; all of them there to remain until Colonel Zarvona is properly exchanged under suitable agreement, or discharged, and permitted to return to this city.

In addition to this case of unusual and severe treatment of a prisoner of war, another and equally glaring instance has been brought to my notice — a case equally appealing to my sense of justice, and calling loudly for redress.

Under a proclamation from the Executive of this State, calling upon the citizens of Northwestern Virginia to organize themselves into companies, to repel the invasion of this State by her enemies, Capt. Daniel Duskey and Lieut. Jacob Vanner, two patriotic officers--one a citizen of Calhoun county and the other a citizen of Jackson county, in this State--organized a small force and took military possession of the town of Ripley, in the county of Jackson, and held it in opposition to the Federal authority and to the usurped Government in Virginia.
While so in possession of this town, they took military possession of the mails, for the purpose of ascertaining the military purposes of the enemy, as they had a right to do by the rules of warfare all over the world.
Sometime afterwards they were overpowered by a much larger force and required to surrender, which they refused to do until their captors — who were soldiers of the United States--agreed that they should be treated as prisoners of war.--After this agreement was made they and the force under them surrendered, and immediately thereafter, in violation of the express stipulation to the contrary, they were taken to the city of Wheeling, confined in jail there, indicted, tried and convicted, and sentenced to the Penitentiary for a term of four years, upon the charge of robbing the mail; and they are now, and have been ever since, confined in the Penitentiary at the city of Washington, treated as common felons.
Both he and his companion, dacob Vanner, are citizens of high character and patriotism, honorable, and heretofore honored by public positions in their counties.
For such violations of the plainest dictates of justice and propriety, and against all the usages of war, some remedy must be found.

I have determined, therefore, to put in execution the principle of retaliation; and I have ordered two of the prisoners captured by Gen. Floyd, to wit: Capt. Wm. Gramm, of Philadelphia, and Lieut Isaac A. Wade, of Putnam county, 8th Virginia reg't, under the usurped Government of Virginia, belonging to the army of the United States, to be also imprisoned in the Penitentiary of this State, and to be kept safely there at hard labor until Capt. Deskey and Lieut. Vanner are either exchanged, under some suitable agreement to be entered into between the Government of the U. States and the State of Virginia, or until they are unconditionally discharged.

And I deem it a duty I owe to the cause of humanity and civilization to hold the residue of the prisoners I now have in custody as well as all who may hereafter come into the possession of this State, as hostages for the good treatment of unoffending citizens of Virginia, who have been incarcerated for no other cause than being loyal to their own State and the Government of their choice — a Government which has in a thousand instances been recognized and acknowledged by the Government of the United States as one of the sovereign and independent States of the former Union, and which they are now waging a hopeless war to restore to its position.

Believing, however, that it would be better for the Government of the United States; better for the Confederate States; better for the individual States; better for the citizens; better for the cause of humanity and civilization, that these departures from the rules of modern warfare should no longer be permitted to exist, I respectfully ask that some arrangement should be made for the proper exchange of the prisoners named, and some agreement be entered into for the exchange of all State prisoners hereafter.
If no such agreement be made, and the course hitherto pursued be continued, I shall, without hesitation, so long as the honor of Virginia and the safety and welfare of her citizens are entrusted to me, as her Chief Magistrate, unflinchingly retaliate, to the utmost of my ability and power, for any improper, unusual, or harsh treatment practiced upon officers, soldiers, or citizens of Virginia.
The sin of its commencement shall rest upon the Government of the United States.
The virtue of its continuance shall be proudly upheld by the authorities of this Commonwealth.

closer.salute: His Excellency Abraham Lincoln, President of the United States.

div3.head: Affairs in Kentucky.
div3.p:
--The Chattanooga Rebel states that information generally credited by the Kentuckians there has been received that the Kentucky Legislature has adjourned under fears of intimidation from the Federal troops.
The Rebel adds:

Dr. W. A. Thompson, an intelligent surgeon, attached to Cheatham's division, who remained behind after the battle of Perryville, assisting in taking care of our wounded, reached here a day or two since, having left Harrodsburg the previous week.
He reports the people completely subjugated, and the only feeling in favor of the South that is manifested is by the ladies, who remain true to our cause and have exhibited their devotion to it in a thousand ways.

There are over thirty thousand Federal troops in Central and Northern Kentucky distributed as follows: At Danville, 3,000; Lexington, 6,000; Frankfort, 2,000; and between Louisville and Frankfort, 6,000.
These hold the people in complete awe, and there is a perfect reign of terrorism prevailing.
Unfortunate as has been the condition of Kentucky since the beginning of the struggle, it is now more deplorable than ever before.
In May, 1861, the late Ex-President Tyler, in a letter to a prominent citizen of Kentucky, wrote the following prophecy in relation to the fate of that State:

Mr. Lincoln, should he find occasion, will laugh to scorn her neutrality, as he has done that of the patient and submissive Governor, not people, of Maryland.
The wealthy proprietors of Louisville, who may regard the security of their town property as of a vast deal more importance than the honor and dignity of Kentucky, will soon rejoice in the occupancy of this city by Mr. Lincoln's troops, and Frankfort be used after the same manner as Annapolis, the proud old capital of Maryland.

Many Kentuckians and many Marylanders have broken the bands, the willow-wyths, in which their free limbs were bound, and are standing on the ramparts of freedom for its protection.
Those noble spirits have desired to encounter all the hazards and risks of the fiery contests which are approaching.
To these all praise and honor is due; their names will be enrolled in the capitol, and live immortal in story.
Virginia will consecrate them, by wearing them in her inmost heart, let their States do what they may.

div3.head: The battle of Seven Pines
div3.p:
--The Official Report at Last Made Public.--After the lapse of nearly a year, the long withheld Yankee official report of the battles of the 31st May and 1st June is made public.
The Tribune gives its material points in the following editorial summary:

Few battles in this war have given rise to more controversy than this one, of which we have, for the first time, the official report.--The question of the conduct of Gen. Casey's division has remained in a measure unsettled ever since.
General Heintzelman's opinion is plainly expressed:

Nothing but the great gallantry of General Kearney, who had a horse shot under him while leading the 37th New York into action, his officers and men, and the steadiness of most of Couch's division, saved us from a most disastrous defeat."

The divisions of Kearney and Couch had been ordered up to reinforce Casey, the condition of whose command may be judged from the statement that "some of the regiments fought gallantly till overpowered by numbers.
After they were once broken, however, they could not be rallied.
The road was filled with fugitives — not all from this division — as far as Bottom's Bridge. Col. Starr's regiment, of Gen. Holmes's division, had to force its way through them with the bayonet, and a guard I placed at Bottom's Bridge stopped over a thousand men."

General Casey's camp, it is well known, was taken; but it has been denied that it was surprised.
Gen. Heintzelman says:

q.p: "An officer informed me that after we had driven the enemy beyond our first entrenchments, he visited Gen. Casey's camp, and found more men bayoneted and shot inside the shelter tents than outside of them."

div3.p:
Most of the ground which was lost was carried by the first rush of the rebels.
After Kearney came up, our force did not fall back a third of a mile.
Gen. Sedwick's arrival late in the afternoon saved the day on the right.

On the next morning General Hooker led the 5th and 6th New Jersey forward near the railroad, and, after some firing, made a gallant charge with the bayonet, leading the two regiments himself, and drove back the rebels nearly a mile.
The ground lost on the first day was recovered on the second, and on the following morning Gen. Hooker, with a portion of his division, pushed forward on a reconnaissance to within five miles of Richmond, driving the enemy's pickets before him as he advanced.
In the afternoon he fell back and occupied the position held by Casey before the battle. "We lost on the first day eight pieces of artillery, and on both days, in the aggregate, 4,000 men, killed, wounded, and missing. "

It is impossible to understand why a report containing facts of such interest has been so long withheld from publication.
While a campaign is in progress silence may be a wise policy, but when military reasons for reticence have ceased to exist, the public has a right to know the facts.
The history of the Peninsula campaign is yet a labyrinth of doubts which only official reports can clear up. They at least ought not to be suppressed with a view to shielding the blunders of any General, or even to hide the mistakes, if such there were, of his superiors.

Good clothing and subsistence furnished by Government.

None other need apply.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 39, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatchs.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all for subscriptive, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed in an , directed to the "Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia," and sealed with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: "Fighting Joe."
div3.p:
Some of the Yankee newspapers accuse this hero of "drinking hard." It is a grow slander.
He sakes it as easy as any hero ever did. It is evidently quite natural to him. A gentleman of our acquaintance, who came home with him from California, says he can bear witness to the fact.
He was on board the steamer nine days, and Joe was dead drunk every day. Many suppose that he obtained his surname from the valor with which he has for many years carried on the war with King Alcohol.
The Temperance Society people once talked of employing him to destroy all the ardent within fifty miles around.
It is a pity the scheme did not succeed.
Precious little liquor would have been left for any other drunkard after Joe had gotten a swig at the bottles.
He would have been a more powerful auxiliary than White or Gough.
They can do no more than preach against the sin of drunkenness.
Joe would have rendered that sin impossible in anybody but himself.
Upon the same principle, no doubt, he is now put in command of the army on the Rappahannock.
That army is demoralized; among other things, by drinking whiskey to excess.
They want a General who will enforce sobriety by drinking all the whiskey himself.

The Yankees, however, assign a different origin to Joe's surname.
The New York Tribune, commenting on Heintzelman's report of the late battle of Seven Place, says: "We not with interest that on the next morning, Gen. Hocker led the 5th and 6th New Jersey forward near the railroad and; after some firing, made a gallant charge with the bayonet, leading the two regiments himself, and drove back the rebels near a mile." There it is. This "charring bayonet" business is a monomania with the Yankees, especially with the Yankee Generals.--They know their men cannot be brought to it, and for that reason they are forever ascribing brilliant bayonet charges to them.
In their secret hearts they admire above all things the men who can make such charges, as Geoffry Hudson, the little dwarf of three-feel, admired a strapping soldier of six and a half.
And for the same reason.
Because they know their men are ticklish, and can't stand the cold steel.
McClellan, among the thousand lies that he fabricated on the Peninsula, could not pass over this favorite theme of Yankee mendacity.--He reported a tremendous charge of bayonets by a brigade of fire eating Yankees in the battle of Williamsburg.
He was met with the lie direct by Gen. Early, upon whose brigade he reported the charge to have been made, and who asserted that the Yankees made no charge during the day. Gen. Early, be it remembered, was on the spot, and had a right to know. McClellan was not on the spot, and had to trust for his facts to an imagination fertile in nothing but lies.
This charge of "fighting Joe's" is equally true with that described by McClellan, and not one particle more so. Indeed, it is a fact attested by every officer who has served in Virginia, that the Yankees who have fought in that State have never once crossed bayonets with any of our troops, and never once attempted to charge, unless upon an enemy already in retreat.--They have been on the other hand, repeatedly charged by our troops and upon no single occasion have they ever stood long enough for the bayonets to cross.
They invariably run before our troops can come in contact with them.
The inability of their troops to stand the test of cold steel has evidently sunk deeply into the Yankee mind.

div4.p: --The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock M. by Mr. Hunter, of Va.

Mr. Baker offered a bill entitled an act to amend the tenth section of "an act to establish the judicial courts of the Confederate States of America, approved March 16th, 1861," which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.
Mr. Johnson, of Ga., introduced a bill for the relief of the Brunswick and Albany Railroad of Georgia, which was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. Wigfall, of Texas, by leave, introduced a bill entitled an act for the establishment and organization of the army of the Confederate States of America.
Referred to Military Committee.

Mr. Orr, of S C., offered a resolution to inquire into the expediency of inquiring what practical plan can be adopted by Congress to secure the endorsement by the several States, jointly or severally, of the bonds of the Confederate States hereafter to be issued to the amount of two hundred millions of dollars.

Mr. Sparrow, of La., submitted a report on the bill further to provide for the public defence.
The committee did not think that all persons liable to conscription who are in the Government offices could be turned adrift and put in the army with safety.
The plan to fill their places by non conscripts was defective.
The committee recommend that the bill do not pass.
The report was agreed to.
Mr. Johnson, of Ga., by leave, introduced a bill to be entitled an act to amend the law in relation to Assistant Treasurers and Depositories, which was referred to the Committee on Finance.

The Senate resumed the consideration of the motion of Mr. Phelan, of Miss, to lay upon the table the Exemption bill reported by the Senate Military Committee, and to take up the House Exemption bill.
The adoption or rejection of this motion had been accepted as a test question of the sense of the Senate on the exemption or conscription of the overseers, and was discussed accordingly by Mr. Johnson, of Ga., Mr. Phelan, of Miss., and others.

At the conclusion of Mr. Phalan's remarks, Mr. Yancey, of Ala., obtained the floor, but yielded to a motion to adjourn over until Monday, which was carried.
The further consideration of the pending bill was then informally passed over until Monday.

Mr. Yancey moved that when the Senate adjourns, it do so to meet at 11 o'clock Monday, and at the same hour each succeeding day till the adjournment.
Disagreed to.

Mr. Wigfall, of Texas, by leave, introduced a bill to amend the act to provide transportation for persons mustered into service for the war, which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.
On motion of Mr. Sparrow, of La., the Senate went into Executive session, and when the doors were thrown open, adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Burrows.
Mr. Atkins, of Tenn., moved to increase the special committee on abuses in railroad transportation to six instead of five, which was agreed to, and Mr. Foote, of Tenn., was appointed chairman.

Resolutions Introduced and Referred.--By Mr. McDowell, of N. C.: A resolution that the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill providing for the sale of all negroes taken in arms against the Confederate States, the proceeds to be divided among the troops engaged in their capture.

Joint Resolution--By Mr. Gartrell, of Ga.: A joint resolution of thanks to Gen. John H. Morgan and the officers and men of his command, for the many heroic deeds performed by them during the war. Referred to Committee on Military Affairs.

Secret Session.--Mr. Foote, of Tenn., moved that the House go into secret session, and on this motion the ayes and noes were called by Mr. Soyston, of Ark., and the call being sustained the ayes and noes were had, with the following result: Ayes 26, noes 48.
So the House refused to go into secret session.
Adjournment till Monday.--Mr. Gartrell, of Ga., moved that when the House adjourn to-day it adjourn to meet at 12 o'clock on Monday next.
On this motion Mr. Jones, of Tenn., called the ayes and noes, which were ordered, and resulted Ayes 41, noes 33.
Reports from Committees--By Mr. Garnett, of Va., from the Military Committee: A bill to allow commutation for deficiencies in rations.

The rules were suspended and the bill taken up for consideration.
An explanation of the object of the bill was made by Mr. Garnett, after which the bill was engrossed, read a third time, and passed.
The following is a copy of the bill, as agreed to:
Whereas, the present army ration has been reduced considerably below the ration allowed by the regulations in force when the army was raised, now, therefore.

The Congress of the Confederate States of America do enact. That the sum of $5 per month shall be paid and allowed to every private and non commissioned officer in lien of commutation for deficiencies in his rations.
The Impressment Bill--The special order — being the bill to authorize and regulars impressments of private property for the use of the army and other military purpose — was taken up.
Mr. Moore, of Ky., being entitled to the floor, addressed the House in support of the bill.
The bill was then considered by sections, and after considerable decision, was adopted by the following vote — ayes 54 nose 7
The following is a copy of the bill as it passed the
A bill to be entitled an act to authorize and regulate impressments of private property for the use of the army and other military purposes.

list.item: Section 1. The Congress of the Confederate State of American do enact: Any officer of the Confederate States commanding a military district or department, may authorise the impressment by an officer, of a grade not lower than Captain, under special order, of property other than the property of a State of the Confederacy, for the use of the army or other necessary military purpose, by order in writing, whenever he is satisfied that the same cannot be procured in due time, except by impressment.

Sec. 2. Where slaves are required to labor on fortifications or other public works, the impressment shall be made in accordance with the law of the State where they are impressed; in the absence of such law, in accordance with rules and regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this act, to be prescribed from time to time by the Secretary of War: Provided, no impressment of slaves shall be made where they can be hired at the usual market rates.

Sec. 3. In no instance shall any individual be deprived, by impressment, of the amount of provisions required for the comfortable support of his family, nor except under circumstances of extreme urgency, to be declared in the order of the commanding General, shall any individual be deprived of the grain, forage, slaves, or other property necessary for the use of his plantation.

Sec. 4. In all cases of impressment, just compensation shall be made for the property seized, whether the absolute ownership or the temporary use or hire only thereof is demanded.
If the owner and the impressing officer cannot agree upon the amount of such compensation, it shall be ascertained and determined by the judgment of three Royal and disinterested freeholders of the city, county, or parish in which the impressment is made--one to be selected by the owner, one by the impressing officer, and the third to be chosen by these two.
The persons thus selected, after taking an oath to appraise the property impressed fairly and impartially, which oath the impressing officer is authorized to administer, shall proceed to assess the full value of the property seized, as well as the amount of compensation for its temporary use or hire, where that only is required; and also to determine, upon the application of the impressing officer, which application is to be made only in extreme cases, what amount of provision would furnish a liberal support for the family of the owner.
And it shall be the duty of such persons to make out a certificate, to be signed by all the parties, in which the valuations herein provided for shall be declared, and the property impressed, where its temporary use or hire only is demanded, described with such minuteness as to identify it, and to deliver one copy thereof to the owner and one to the impressing officer.

Sec. 5. Where property has been impressed for temporary use or hire, and is lost or destroyed without the default of the owner, the Confederate States shall pay the full value thereof, as ascertained under the provisions of this act. If such property, when returned, has in the opinion of the owner, been injured whilst in the public use, the amount of damage thereby sustained shall be determined in the manner prescribed in the fourth section of this act, the officer returning the property being authorized to act on behalf of the Confederate States; and upon such inquiry, the certificate of the value of the property, when originally impressed, shall be received as conclusive evidence thereof.

Sec. 6. Any officer of the Confederate States impressing property in violation of the provisions of this act shall be liable to such punishment as the military court of the district or department to which he belongs may in its discretion inflict unless compliance with the requirements thereof be prevented by the owner of the property or by the public enemy.
And in the latter event the impressing officer shall be liable to the penalties of this section, unless he shall cause the property seized to be appraised, in the manner pointed out in this act, as soon as practicable; or, if this be impossible, by reason of the occupation of the enemy, then, by an appraisement in the city, county, or parish, most convenient to that in which the property was impressed.
On motion of Mr. Foote, of Tenn, the House adjourned.

div4.p: --The Senate met at noon, Mr. Johnson in the chair, the Lieut.-Governor, Mr. Montague, being called out of the city by urgent business.--Prayer by Rev. Mr. Pettigrew.

A communication from the House transmitted Senate bills entitled "A bill to enlarge the powers of the City Council of Richmond; ' and ' A bill authorizing the sale of the Roanoke Valley Railroad," with House amendments to each, in which they asked the concurrence of the Senate.
The amendments were concurred in, and the bills tabled.

Committee Bills--From the Committee on Confederate Relations: "A bill to transfer the State Line to the Confederate Government." From the Committee for Courts of Justice: "A bill to authorize movements for the support of the families of soldiers and of the poor."

Resolutions of Expediency and Inquiry.--By Mr. Quisenberry: Requesting the Governor to inform the Senate why the Congressional districts have not been provided with the amount of salt, according to the terms of the contract with the proprietors of the salt works of Smyth and Washington By Mr. Greever: Providing for the payment to William W. Booker, jailor of Washington county, for certain expenses incurred.
By Mr. Douglass: Providing for a connection between the Danville and the Richmond and York River Railroads.
By Mr. Lynch: Providing for the meeting of the Senate after Monday next at 11 o'clock A. M. until further ordered.
By Mr. Brannon: In relation to coupon bonds in the hands of alien enemies; authorizing persons indebted to any bank or branch within the enemy's lines to pay the same to the parent bank, or some branch bank in the city of Richmond; repealing an act by which George W. Thompson one of the Circuit Judges of the Commonwealth, was deprived of his salary.
Numerous bills were read the first and second times, and put upon their passage.
The bill increasing the salaries of the Secretary of the Commonwealth, Auditor of Public Accounts, Treasurer, and Register of Land Office, was taken up from the calendar of unfinished business.

Mr. Douglass moved to strike out the Secretary of the Commonwealth, Treasurer, and Superintendent of the Penitentiary from the bill; but the Senate refused, and the bill was engrossed and read the third time, and laid upon the table.
The preamble and resolution urging an increase of pay to the non-commissioned officers and soldiers in the Confederate service, was adopted.

Bills Passed.--Concerning the estate of John Haskins a lunatic; charging the time of holding the Circuit Courts of the 14th circuit; amending an act repealing he fence law, and extending the provisions of the act to certain other counties.
The Senate adjourned.
--The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Jeter.
Mr. R. H. Carter, the member elect from the county of Albemarle, appeared, took the oath of office, and was admitted to his seat upon the floor of the House.
Various reports were made by the committees of the House, among them one from the Committee on Military Affairs, reorganizing the State troops under the command of Gen. J. B. Floyd.

Mr. Hopkins, from the Committee on Extortion, moved that the functions of that committee be extended, and that they be allowed to send for persons and papers for examination.
Agreed to.
The bill authorizing the issue of Treasury notes of a less denomination than one dollar was taken up and read, and on motion of Mr. Hunter, was laid upon the table.
Mr. Rives moved a suspension of the rules to take up the bill making an additional appropriation of $80,000 to the Cenwe Lunatic Asylum, which was agreed to and the bill pasted — ayes 70 noes 9.
The bill was communicated to the Senate for its concurrence.
On motion of Mr. Hunter, the bill relative to the issue of small notes, just laid on the table, was called up, and ordered to its engrossment.

[The bill provides for the issuing of Treasury notes of the denomination of 10,25, and 50 cents, to an amount not exceeding $1,500,000; with an amendment proposed by Mr. Hunter, making them redeemable in such funds as are receivable for dues to the State and bearing upon their face the words "may be redeemed in Confederate notes."]
Mr. Oszenove moved to further amend the bill by authorizing the Auditor to employ females to sign said notes which was agreed to.

Several gentlemen having recorded their votes in opposition to the Lunatic Asylum appropriation bill under a misapprehension of the amount appropriated, the Senate was requested to return the same to the House, which was done, and the bill again passed.
The bill relative to changing the fence laws, &c., in certain counties, was taken up, and the Senate's amendments agreed to.

Mr. Pitman submitted a resolution, which was laid over under the rules that when the House adjourns to-morrow at 3 o'clock they adjourn to meet at 11 o'clock Monday, and at that hour each day thereafter until otherwise ordered.
The bill amending an ordinance of the Convention relative to the appointment of Aids by the Governor, was taken up.

[The bill allows the Governor to appoint, during the war, as many Aids as he may deem proper, with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel of cavalry, but only one of whom shall receive pay, perquisites, or emoluments of any sort, during the same year, and that one the pay of a Captain of cavalry.]
On motion, the words "during the same year" were stricken out.

Mr. Anderson, of Botetourt, moved to amend the bill by striking out the indefinite number of Aids, and restricting the Governor to the appointment of three, one of whom shall receive pay, &c., which was agreed to.
A promiscuous discussion of some length was indulged in during the consideration of the subject; but the bill being finally put upon its passage, resulted — ayes, 56; noes, 9.
On motion, the House adjourned.

div3.head: From Fredericksburg.
div3.p:
"Who would not be a soldier — fighting for the d — n nigger?" was heard from a lonesome Yankee picket across the river, as he trudged his damp and muddy round the other night.
Few and far between these angels of darkness now appear.
Their guns still frown upon us; but tents and wagons and men and noises are reduced in number, frequency, and volume.
Probably the bulk of Hock the Potomac in exhibit the condition of the army of the Potomac, both officers and men," to Hornner's Committee on the Conduct of the War," and repair their shattered morals and secure their wavering "devotion to the declared policy of the Government"--that is to the emancipation proclamation.
Let the picket's exclamation above show the necessity for the backward movement and the chance of its success.

Another illustration of Yankee courage and entences was afforded by a prisoner's reply, during the battle of Fredericksburg, to the question "why the Yankees always throw down their guns when they ran, or retreated, thereby losing their only weapon of defence?" He said, if he was caught it made no difference, and if he escaped without his gun he was sent to the rear, and would have to fight no more that day.

Speaking of the battle of Fredericksburg, I see the London Times says "the Fredericksburg News has created a great sensation in Europe. " I always thought the News was a good newspaper, and not appreciated in Fredericksburg.
You see it has found an echo across the Atlantic, and jarred the European mind.
You need not assert that the Times refers to the news of the battle.

The only battle which has occurred here since the 13th December was an engagement in which about 15,000 soldiers took part.
It came on soon after the late heavy fall of snow, and was conducted "with all the pomp and circumstance of glorious war"--with snow balls. Skirmishers were thrown out, signals were made by a soldier on a hogshead with a handkerchief, volleys flew thick as hall; prisoners were taken--"the alarm, the struggle, the relief"--even skulking stragglers were seen; one bald headed Colonel was mercilessly pelted; the retreat and pursuit, all afforded a grand exhibition; and although many were wounded and their mangled remains to fled over mercilessly in the snow, out of 15,000 engaged not one was killed.

The McLawn Minstrels gave one of their laugh provoking and side splitting entertainments on Wednesday night. Ridley, I think, is Manager and an excellent actor.
The burlesque of the Surgeon — his roughness to the sick and monotonous prescriptions of the same medicine for all diseases, and refusal to give whiskey, while he drank it himself, with the numerous patients just before a battle — were all admirably set forth.
The Daguerreotypist, &c., were also amusing; whilst the singing and instrumental music were very fine.
Such entertainments amuse, and therefore benefit, the soldier.
They will be continued.

The Corporation Court held its unusual monthly term yesterday, after three months intermission, and the town may now be presumed to have revived its legal existence.
Those who are disposed to aid it in misfortune, and extend assistance to its wants, would do well to forward contributions to its legal authorities and representatives, who are pre to be most capable of disbursing them, and can be held accountable.

div3.head: Kentucky, Indiana, and Illinois.
div3.p: --A telegram from Frankfort, Ky., published in the Cincinnati Commercial, of the 30th ult., says:

q.p:
The rebels, under the name of the Peace Department, hold a caucus here to-nigh.
A great many prominent traitors from this State are present and many from Ohio Indiana, and Illinois.

div3.p:
The Judiciary Committee in the Senate reported a bill, to-day, to repeal the law passed last August requiring school teachers to take an oath.
After a spirited discussion, it was referred to another committee.

In the House of Representatives a bill came up to pay the nine months soldiers.
Zeb Ward offered an amendment, making a condition that they should not fight to enforce the President's proclamation.
This elicited a warm discussion.
Many prominent Union men declared that when the question came up between the Government and slavery that they were for the Government.
The bill was recommitted.
The Indianapolis correspondent communicates thus:

q.p: I am informed that letters have been received here from members of the Kentucky and Illinois Legislatures in which they promise to meet the Indiana Legislature at Louisville, Ky., on the 22d of February.

div3.p: On which the Commercial remarks:

q.p:
A movement has been set on foot in the Indiana Legislature for a grand pow-wow of the Legislatures of Kentucky, Illinois, and Indiana, at Louisville; on the 22d of February next.
It seems to us the Hooslers are invidious, and manifest unnecessary exclusiveness in refusing or neglecting to embrace Ohio in their invitation.
We think Ohio could bring her share of intellectual greatness and legislative wisdom to such a convocation, with advantage to herself.
Think, for instance, of having Dr. Olds as a feature in such a jubilation — a martyr, an orator, and a member in good and regular standing in an evangelical Church for two years, more or less!

div3.p: Over 500 men have gone to the camp of instruction at Atlanta, Ga., during this week, and volunteered in various companies to avoid conscription.

div3.head: The city Gas Works.
div3.p:
--The city gas, for some weeks past, has gives, most of the time, a rather dim and unsatisfactory light.
Its quality is said to be effected by the want of retorts, the latter not being supplied in sufficient quantities to insure a good article of gas. The needed articles, we learn have been received, and the city will no doubt soon rejoice in an ample supply of good gas. A description of the gas works, which are located at Rocketts, may not be uninteresting to the reader: The retort-house measures 122 feet by 55 feet, is of brick, covered with a roof of corrugated iron, supported by wrought iron rafters and girders, ventilation top. In this there are twelve block of benches of retorts, three to a bench.
Near by is a coal shed 122 feet long, 28 feet wide, 12 feet high under the joists, brick and tinned roof, capable of storing 40,000 bushels of coal.
Near by are the washers, consisting of four tiers of 18 inch cylinders 18 feet high, and the condensers, formed of 40 tiers of 10 inch pipe 20 feet high.
The purifying-house is 66 feet long by 34 feet wide, of brick, and iron roof, and divided into two rooms.
In the larger of these are four dry lime purifiers, measuring 15 feet by 10 feet, which have in them five sets of screens for layers of lime.
The gas is received into these for purification.
It goes thence into the metre and afterwards in the street main.
In the purifying-house is the station metre, ½ feet in diameter, 10 feet in length.
This metre is capable of registering 400,000 feet of gas in 24 hours, and weight 12 tons.

div3.head: The Penitentiary.
div3.p:
--Sundry changes have lately occurred in the personel of the officers of this institution.
The following have lately resigned: Jno Jacobs, for 40 years deputy Superintendent; John Fresman, for 10 years overseer of the carpenter's department, and Lewis B. Jones, overseer in the shoe department.
Caleb Jacob succeeded Mr. Freeman, and Mr. James Lee (formerly of Ireland, but late of Washington, D. C.,) Mr. Jones. Col. Chas. Blue of Hampshire, is now general Superintendent succeeding James F. Pendleton.

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p: --The alarm of fire about 12 o'clock on Thursday night was caused by the burning of a chimney on Main street. The alarm last night, at 8½ o'clock was caused by the burning of a house in Rocketts old field beyond the corporation limits.

div3.head: Dress parades of the city Battalion.
div3.p:
--The dress parades of the City Battalion on the Capital Square were resumed last evening.
A very large number of ladies and gentlemen were attracted to the spot to witness the parade and listen to the delightful music of Smith's band.

div3.head: The Medical Department.
div3.p:
--Dr. S. P. Moore, the Surgeon General of the Confederate States, has added to his corps of immediate assistants.
Surgeon Thos. H. Williams, formerly Medical Director of General Johnston, has been attached to his office.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p: --Present, James K. Caskle, Recorde; Richard D. Sanxay, Senior Alderman; Jas. Bray, N. C. Lipscombe, and Jno. F. Regnault, Aldermen.

Samuel Stanley, indicted for misdemeanor, falling to make his appearance in accordance with the condition of a recognizance entered into before Recorder Caskle, 30th December, for that purpose, a espies was awarded to bring him into court.
The case against Richard Capeland, for misdemeanor, was continued until the March term of the court, defendant giving ball for his appearance at that time.

Mary Vanderlip, who gave ball January 30th, to appear before the court, for trial for misdemeanor, falling to answer, as likewise did the Commonwealth's witnesses, a espies was awarded against all said parties.

George W. Nelson was tried for misdemeanor, which consisted in resisting officer Seal while the latter was endeavoring to quell a disturbance among the inmates of the jail.
He was found guilty, and fined $0 and costs, by the jury, and ordered by the court to be imprisoned for six months in the jail, and during that time to be put at labor, under the direction of the City Council, on the public streets, in the city quarries, or upon such other public work as the said Council may direct, for eight hours a day, during the said term of six months.

The case of James G. Duffy and Charles Johnson charged with having, on the 23th of January, put Thomas Moser in bodily fear and stolen from him $32 in C. S. Treasury notes, was continued until the next term.
A second case against George W. Nelson, for misdemeanor, was dismissed by entry of a noble prosequi
Jos. B. Apperson was tried for committing an assault on a man named Jack Moore, and the jury having heard the evidence, returned a verdict of not guilty.

Miss Anna Thompson was set to the bar for trial on an indictment charging her with keeping a house of ill-fame at the corner of Cary and 12th streets. The proof adduced failed to substantiate the charge and the jury found the defendant not guilty.
Thomas C Dobbs was tried for misdemeanor and found guilty by a jury, and fined ten dollars and the costs of prosecution, which he paid to the Clerk in Court and was discharged.
Thomas Tardy being led to the bar to be tried for misdemeanor, plead guilty, whereupon the Court ordered him to be confined in the jail for the space of 20 days.

Grand Jury Presentments.--The grand jury of the Hustings Court assembled yesterday at the City Hall, and were sworn in, George W. Smith sundry will they indicated the following parties for misdemeanor, viz: Thomas M. Dobbs, John Sharpe, and James G. Davis.
The grand jury were then discharged for the term.
The said grand jury also made a presentment against Harry Vanderlin for perjury.
The bills of indictment against John Webb, for misdemeanor, were ignored by the grand jury.

div4.p:
--A few persons of "African descent," arrested for various petty offences, were the only prisoners in the box to-day.
Two of the number, named William Henry Ross and John Robertson, were charged with stealing $22 from Alfred, a slave, and had been sent before His Honor by the Hustings Court to be examined for larceny, instead of robbery, the charge on which they had previously been sent on by the Mayor.--The case proved not to be ready, none of the witnesses responding when called, and it was, therefore continued until Saturday.
The Courts.--The C. S. District Court, Supreme Court of Appeals, and County Court of Henrico were all in session yesterday, but did nothing worthy of public mention.

div3.head: From Charleston.
div3.p:
--The French war steamer Milan passed our bar yesterday, from Baltimore, bound to Port Royal.
She is expected here this week.
The frigate Ironsides maintains her position permanent among the blockading squadron off Charleston.

A Yankee picket was captured Wednesday evening, by our scouts, on Hilton Head Island.--He confirms the intelligence of an impending attack on Charleston, and thinks it will be made in about a fortnight.

He was purchased by me in Richmond last fall, and formerly belonged to Wm Woodfin, Cumberland county, about whose place he is supposed to be lurking I will pay the above reward if delivered to C W Coleman, near Ashland, or lodged in some jail so I get him again.

div4.head: Obituary
div4.p:
Died, on Monday, December 22d, 1863, at 20 minutes to 11 A. M., after a long and painful attack of inflammatory rheumatism, Mr. William B Hudson, in the 36th year of his age, who was esteemed and beloved by all who knew him for his goodness, kindness of heart, and gentleness of spirit.
He was always ready to help any one when he saw them in distress; always had a kind word and feeling for every one; indeed, he possessed qualities far beyond my feeble utterance.

Mr. Hudson was a resident of Hanover county for several years, when last Spring him and his family were driven from their beautiful home they loved so much by the Yankees; his loss by the enemy was very heavy, but I never heard him once complain.
His trust was in God, whom he knew ordained all things for the best, and who is always too wise to err. He was a member of the Presbyterian church for several years, and we have every reason to believe that he has gone to a world where there is no pain and trouble, but where peace and happiness reign forever.
He leaves a devoted wife and two affectionate children, with many other relatives and friends, to mourn their irreparable loss; cheered, however, by the consolation that their loss is his eternal gain.
Peace to his ashes.

div3.head: From Tennessee — reported Evacuation of Murfreesboro'.
div3.p:
The Chattanooga Rebel, of Monday, has a rumor that Fort Donelson had been captured by Morgan, Wheeler, and Forrest, who had joined their forces for the attack.
This is hardly probable, as the Northern papers publish an official dispatch from Rosecrans of the 7th inst, giving an account of the repulse of our troops.
The following rumor, from the same paper, receives partial confirmation from a letter received in this city yesterday:

It also was currently rumored, and generally believed, on the streets yesterday forenoon, that the Yankees were evacuating Murfreesboro', and destroying large quantities of stores.
Our fellow citizen, Mr. Leiper, late of the firm of Leicer & Menifee, of Murfreesboro', has received information that the large warehouse belonging to that firm, has been destroyed by the Yankees in that place.
This was the principal storehouse in the place.

div3.head: The army of Tennessee.
div3.p: The following highly complimentary order has been issued by Gen. Johnston to the Army of Tennessee:

div4.head:
Heat quarters,
Chattanooga, January 28, 1863.
div4.p: General Orders, No. 4.

General Johnston has great satisfaction in expressing to this command his sense of the high services and admirable conduct of the Army of Tennessee, especially in the recent operations near Murfreesboro'. In those operations that patriotic army, contending with greatly superior numbers by its own courage and the skill of its General, inflicted upon the enemy a loss almost equal to its own number, besides capturing thirty-three cannon and a thousand wagons — an exploit unparalleled in modern battles.
For its heroic fortitude in enduring fatigue, privation and exposure, and bravery in battle, he can, with confidence, promise to it the thanks of the Government and gratitude of the country.
div4.closer:
By command of Gen. Johnston.
(Signed) B. S. Ewell, A. A. General.
