div3.head: To the Voters of Virginia.
div3.p: --Fellow-citizens: Having been requested by many of you to become a candidate for the office of Governor at the regular election in May next, I respectfully announce that I cheerfully yield to such request, and, in the event of my election, will diligently and to the best of my ability perform the duties of the position.

I am sensible of the responsibilities which I announce my willingness to assume.
I am painfully aware of the giant struggle which is in progress and that it may be my duty to assume such responsibilities without counting the cost to myself.
In such event I shall unhesitatingly do so only asking the liberal construction of my fellow-citizens for my vindication and defence.

I regret that it will not be in my power to appear among you and address you upon public affairs.
But, having deemed it my duty to adhere to the army, to which, after a confinement of some months, I am about to return, I shall not have an hour to spare for any other purpose.
I regret this the less, however, as I flatter myself that I am sufficiently well known to you in person, or by reputation, to enable you to exercise the sovereign power of suffrage with all proper intelligence.

With no parties to divide us — with but one great impulse — that which seeks to protect our liberties and establish our independence — we surely can work together with one will to realize this vital consummation.
At any rate, if elected, I shall seek to deserve your confidence by devoting to the duties of my position all the powers of mind and body which I possess.
Believing, if true to ourselves, that a gracious Providence will crown our righteous and glorious efforts with success, I have the honor to be, most respectfully and cordially, your fellow citizen.

div3.head:
Depot army Committee, Y. M. C. A.
and ladies' soldiers' aid Society,
Richmond, October 24th, 1862.
div3.p: clothing for the army.--The Committee will receive at their depot, corner of 10th and Bank streets, whatever contributions in clothing, such as blankets, coverlets, shoes, socks, coats, pants, shirts, &c., the citizens may furnish for the purpose, and forward them wherever they are most needed.
The citizens are reminded of the importance of doing all that they can for the comfort and health of our defenders in the field.

div3.head: By the Governor of Virginia.--a proclamation.
div3.p: --Information having been received by the Executive, that a murder was committed by James Harris, a deserter from the 56th Virginia regiment, on the 10th instant in the county of Buckingham, upon the person of A. Baldwin, Jr., and that the said Jame; Harris has fled from justice and is now going at large: Therefore, I do hereby offer a reward of two Hundred Dollars to any person or persons who shall arrest the said James Harris and deliver him into the jail of said county; and I do moreover require all officers of this Commonwealth civil and military, and request the people generally, to use their best exertions to procure the arrest of the said Harris that he may be brought to justice.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the Lesser Seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 13th day of February, in the year 1863.
div3.closer:
John Letcher.
By the Governor:
Geo. W. Munford,
Sec'y of the Commonwealth.
James Harris is a large, stout man about 6 feet high, weighing from 165 to 170 pounds; dark hair, eyes, and complexion, and has either a very badly decayed tooth in front or has lost a front tooth. fe 17--aw3

div3.head: By Hill, Dickinson & Co., Auct's.
div3.p:
Receivers sale of Negroes.--By virtue of two degrees of the District Court of the Confederate States in and for the Eastern District of Virginia, I shall, on Monday, the 16th instant, at 10 o'clock, at the auction rooms of Hill, Dickinson & Co., sell for cash, four Slaves, consisting of a man, a boy, and two women.
One of the women is said to be a good Cook.

div3.head: Beautiful Improved farm, near Charlottesville, and twelve or Fifteen Negroes, for sale.
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemarle, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vs. Crawford and als," the undersigned Commissioners will offer for sale, at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 3d day of March, 1863, (or the next fair day,) a beautiful estate, known as Meadow Creek, containing about 600 acres. This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia; has an abundance of timber; is smooth and gently undulating, susceptible of a high degree of improvement; has a large creek passing entirely through the place, affording a quantity of fine meadow land, well set in old grass, yielding a large quantity of hay; and there is a spring of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling-house, and all the necessary out houses, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, is offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same time and place, 12 or 15 likely Negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture, a fine Piano, two good Mitch Cows, &c.
Terms--Pretty much at the option of the purchaser.

div3.head: Commissioner's sale of Land, Slaves and other property, in the county of Hanover.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to a decree of Hanover County Court, entered on the 27th January, 1863, I shall offer for sale to the highest bidder, at public auction, at the residence of the late Robert Anderson, near Old Church, in the county of Hanover, on Friday, the 27th day of February, 1863, a tract of land called "Person's," lying about three or four miles from the Old Church, containing about one hundred acres. Also, sixteen likely Slaves, consisting of men, women, and children.
Also, all the Farming Implements and Household and Kitchen Furniture now in the possession of Mrs. Mary F. Anderson.

Terms.--For the slaves and parishable property cash will be required.
For the land, one-third cash, and the balance upon a credit of one and two years, with interest from the day of ; or all cash, at the option of the purchaser.
If credit be given, bond and good personal security will be required, and the title retained until the purchase money is all paid.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.

Eight or the Likely Negroes will be sold to the highest bidder, for cash, at Powhatan Station, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad on Saturday, the 14th of February, 1863.
The sale is for a division under a decree of the County Court of Powhatan in the case of administrator vs. Forces and others.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 39, page 4.

div3.head:
Vicksburg.
by Paul M. Hayne.

lg.l: I.
For sixty days and upwards,
A storm of shall and shot
Rained bound us in a flaming shower,
But still we filtered not!
"If the noble city perish,"
Our grand young lander said,
"Let the only walls the foe shall scale.
Be ramparts of the dead."
II.
For sixty days and upwards
The eye of Heaven waxed dim,
And even throughout God's holy morn,
O'er Christian's prayer and hymn,
Arose a hiering tumult.
As if the fiends of air
Strove to engulf the voice of faith
In the shrieks of their despair.
III.
There was walling in the houses.
There was trembling on the marts,
While the tempest raged and thundered,
Mid the silent thrill of hearts;
But the Lord, our shield, was with us,
And are a month had aped,
Our very women walked the streets.
With scarce one throb of dread.
IV.
And the little children gamboled--
Their faces purely raised,
Just for a wondering moment,
As the huge bombs whirled and blazed!
Then turned with silvery laughter
To the sports which children love.
Thrice mailed in the sweet, instinctive thought.
That the good God watched above.*
V.
Yet the hailing boils fell faster,
From scores of flame clad ships,
And about us, denser, darker,
Grew the conflict's wild calibre;
Till a solid cloud closed o'er us,
Like a type of doom and ire,
Whence shot a thousand quivering tongues
Of forked and vengeful fire.
VI.
But the unseen hands of angels
Those death shafts turned aside,
And the dove of heavenly mercy
Ruled o'er the battle tide;
In the houses ceased the walling,
And through the war scarred marts
The people trode with the step of hope
To the music in their hearts.

div3.p: * It has been stated by one professing to have witnessed the fact that some weeks after the beginning of this terrific bombardment, not only were ladies seen coolly walking the streets, but that in some parts of the town children were observed at play, only interrupting their sports to gaze and listen to the bursting shells.

div3.head: Administrator's notice.
div3.p:
--Being anxious to settle up the estate of Alson Richards as soon as possible, I request that all persons indebted to it will at once come forward and settle.
All claims against the estate, it properly authenticated, will be paid upon presentation to the undersigned, at Williamson & Co.'s auction-room, on Governor at, one door above Franklin.

div3.head: Eight Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --A reward of $100 each is offers for the following named privates of company F, 19th Va. regiment:

James Gaffney, a short, stout man, sandy hair and beard, blue eyes, about 35 years olds enlistes as a substitute near Richmond, about August 8, 1863; called himself a Kentuckian, and had a discharge from the 1st Kentucky regiment.
John Hogam, a short, stout Irishman; black hair and eyes, about 5 feet 7 inches high looks about 30 years old; will be found near Richmond; enlisted as a substitute in December, 1862.
Martin Kelley, about 5 feet 10 inches high, very dark complexion, dark hair, thin dark beard, supposed to have enlisted in the 4th Virginia cavalry.
Richard Matthews, an Irishman; sandy hair and beard, about 5 feet 9 inches high.

div3.head:
Camp Mn. Va. Battalion,
Fields's Brigade, A. P. Hill's division,
February 5th, 1863.
div3.p: Thirty Dollars reward.--A reward of $30 each will be paid for the arrest and the delivery to me of any one of the following named deserters:
Stepfano Couovick, an Italian, with very dark, complexion, black eyes and hair, and about 6 feet 8 inches high; age, 28 years.
Augustus Kaisre, a German, with light complexion, blue eyes and light hair, about 5 feet 10 inches high, and 22 years of age.

J. E. Phelphs, halls from Lynchburg, says he is a Kentuckian by birth, and was employed on the James River and Kanawha Canal for some time previous to enlistment; complexion dark, dark eyes and hair, 6 feet high, and about 24 years of age.

div3.head:
Camp near Port Royal,
January 30, 1863.
div3.p: Arrest the Deserters — The usual reward of $30 will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me, or to the officer in command of Castle Thunder, Richmond city, of the following deserters from Company "A," 8th Regiment Louisiana Volunteers:

list.item:
1. Private Jasboyd, a native of Ireland, about 32 years of age, red hair and beard, ruddy complexion, marked by the small pox, somewhat over 6 feet in height, and a teamster by occupation.
He is supposed to have joined a Virginia cavalry company.
2. Private Jno. H. Cummins, a native of New York State, 21 years old, light hair no beard, fair complexion, blue eyes, about 5 feet 7 inches high, and a painter by trade.
3. Private Patrick Donahoe, a native of Ireland, about 37 years old, light black hair, ruddy complexion, quick of speech and motion, about 5 feet 5½ inches high, and a gardener by trade.
4. Private Patrick Fitzgerald, a native of Ireland, near 60 years of age, black hair and beard, slightly bald, black eyes, about 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, and a day laborer.

5. Private Wm. Reagan, a native of New York State 30 years old, auburn hair, hazel eyes, stout built, some 5 feet 7 inches high, and a blacksmith by trade.
He decented in the early part of last June, and is supposed to be in Richmond city, and lately received a notice from Capt. West, one of the Quartermasters of that city, that he had paid him $174,58 as pay, bounty, and clothing money.
I will add $20 for Resgan's arrest, thus making the reward in his case $50.

closer.signed: Capt. co. A, 8th Reg. La. Vols.

div3.head: Thirty Dollars reward.
div3.p: --The above reward will be paid for the apprehension of any one of the following named Deserters from the Alexandria Light Artillery--camp near Richmond:
Jno. Robertson: Gray eyes, dark hair, florid complexion, 5 feet 16½ inches high, aged 45 years, born in Ireland.
Timothy Ragan: Light eyes, brown hair, florid complexion, 6 feet high, born in Ireland, aged 45 years.
Thomas Connee: Blue eyes, light hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high, born in Ireland, aged 46 years.
Jno. Davis: Hazel eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 9½ inches high; born in England.
Chas Heslin: Blue eyes, black hair with a sprinkling of gray, dark complexion, 5 feet 11 inches high, born in Ireland aged 45 years.

div3.head: One Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Left my company, (A, 53d, Va. reg't.) on or about the 7th day of January, 1863 Thomas McLEAN.
He is about 5 feet 8 inches high, with dark hair.--The middle finger of his right hand has been cut off just below the second joint.
On the back of the other hand is a large India ink. He also has a small sing in his right ear. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me, at the camp of the 53d Va. reg't. Armistead's brigade, Pickett's division, near Chines Station.

div3.head: Last chance for Absentees.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to orders issued by Major General G. W. Smith, all members of Capt. J. Hatley Norton's company, (D) 18th Battalion Virginia Heavy Artillery, now absent, are notified that they must report to me at once, and no punishment will be inflicted except the forfeiture of pay for the time absent.--Should they not report immediately, they will be considered as deserters and tried by the new coast-martial now in session in Richmond; and if found guilty, will be shot whenever apprehended.
I can be found at the Military Hall, over the Old Market, corner of 17th and Main streets, Richmond, Va.
div3.closer:
W. T. Chalkley,
Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer,
Co. D, 18th Va. Bat. fe 10--1aw2t*

div3.head: Thirty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at Marine Camp, Drewry's Bluff, of Wm. Myers, a deserter from the C. S. Marine Corps.
He is 23 years of age, 5 feet 8¾ inches high, blue eyes, light hair, fair complexion.
He had been wounded in the left hand supposed in escaping from Camp Lee, where he had engaged himself as a substitute.
div3.closer:
A. S. Taylor,
Major and Q. M. C. S. M. C,
Office 115 Broad st. fe 12--6t

div3.head:
Headq'rs 14th Tennessee Reg't,
Archer's Brigade, Jan. 17, 1863.
div3.p: Lift of Absentees, without leave, from the 14th Tennessee Regiment, viz:
The above-named members of this regiment are hereby ordered to report at once to this command, in person or by Surgeon's certificate, or they will be treated as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Wm, McCome
W. E. Murford, Adj't. ja 21--6t*

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p: --From my camp, at Varina, about the 5th of November, 1863;
Edgar J. Hinston, 36 years of age; 5 feet 10½ inches high; gray eyes; light brown hair; light complexion; was born in Ireland; is decent in appearance; has a youthful voice.
G. P. Duncan, 29 years of age; hazel eyes, dark hair; 5 feet 7½ inches high; enlisted in Westmoreland county, Va., by Capt. Sanford.
L. P. Newman, aged 21 years; blue eyes; light hair, dark complexion; 5 feet 7 inches high; enlisted in Richmond county, Va., by Lieut, Marwood.
J. H. Beyant, aged 26 years; gray eyes; light hair; dark complexion; 5 feet 5½ inches high; enlisted in Westmoreland county, Va., by Capt. Sandford.
E. W. Relley, aged 13 years; hazel eyes; dark hair; dark complexion; 5 feet 4½ inches high; enlisted in Westmoreland county, Va., by Capt. Sandford.
A. S. King, aged 18 years; gray eyes; dark hair; dark complexion; 5 feet 6½ inches high; enlisted in Westmoreland county, Va., by Capt. Sandford.
Samuel French aged 21 years; gray eyes; dark hair; dark complexion; 5 feet 6¼ inches high; enlisted in Westmoreland county, Va., by Capt. Sandford.
The above six men were conscripts and deserted from my camp, at Varina, Nov'r 13, 1862.

Fresck Schnieder, (conscript's substitute,) enlisted of Richmond city, Va., by Lieut, Colonial J. C. Shields, aged, about 35 years; hazel eyes; dark hair; dark complexion; 5 feet 6½ inches high; born in Germany; deserted from camp at Chafina's farm, Nov'r 23, 1862.
A reward of $30 will be paid for the apprehension of each, if placed in jail, so that I get them.
div3.closer:
G. A. Wallace, Capt. Comp'y F,
59th Va. reg't. Wise Brigade. de 2--14

div3.p: Deserted from my Camp, as Housffin's Farm, Sunday night, Nov, 23d, 1862:
James Galvin, aged 23 years; 5 feet 7 inches high, brown eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, born in New York.
Patrice Golden, aged 25 years, 5 feet 3½ inches high, dark hazel eyes, dark brown hair, dark complexion, born in Ireland.
Thirty dollars reward will be paid for the apprehension of each and delivery to any G. S. prison.
div3.closer:
G. A. Wallace, Capt. Co. L
41th Va. reg't, Wise Brigade. se 27--14

div3.p:
By Special Orders, No. 35, issued by command of Major-Gen. G. W. Smith, I am detailed on Recruiting service, for the city of Richmond, and Hanover, Louisa, Albemarle, Orange, and Culpeper counties.
The "letter of instructions" accompanying the order directs the announcement of "the partial suspension of the operation of the Conscript law, so as to allow conscripts to volunteer in the companies of their own selection, without passing through camps of instruction, and receive the bounty and other benefits provided by law for volunteers;" and authorizes me, "upon application, to muster conscripts into any company they may select." Those instructions are used upon the following language, contained in the circular letter front Adjutant and Inspector General Cooper, to Major-Gen. G. W. Smith, commanding Army of North Carolina: "Such persons as are liable to conscription will be allowed to join any particular company and regiment requiring recruits within the command in which the officers may be serving.
In like manner, such persons as are within conscript ages (between 18 and 40) and who may come forward and offer themselves for service, will be allowed to volunteer and will receive all the benefits which are secured by law to volunteers."

In pursuance of these orders and instructions, I have established my headquarters at Gordonsville, Orange county, Va., where all persons interested, who reside in Louisa, Orange, Albemarle, and Culpeper counties, will report, while those in Hanover, and Richmond city, and vicinity, can either address me by letter as before indicated, or call on Mr. O. F. Whisiger, No. 24 Pearl street, Richmond.
An opportunity is hereby afforded all persons within the limits before recited who are liable to military service to discharge themselves of that obligation without incurring the odium which is supposed to attach to the term conscript.
I will receive recruits upon the terms already stated for the company to which I am attached, or for any company in the command of Maj.-Gen. Smith.

The Major-General Commanding, as well as the Adjutant and Inspector-General, earnestly desires that the able-bodied men of the State shall promptly act upon this suggestion, and with a willing zeal come forward and fill up the ranks of the companies in the service without waiting to be considerable to duty.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
--to the citizens of Henrico.--The undersigned having been detailed for thirty days on recruiting service for the county of Henrico, hereby announces to — its citizens the partial suspension of the conscript not, so as to allow all conscripts in this county to volunteer in companies of their own selection in this division, and thereby receive the usual bounty of $50 rewarded to volunteers.
It is earnestly hoped that these inducements will add a large number of men to the ranks of the army.
I call upon the people of this county to assist me in the good work.
Let every man apply his shoulder to the wheel, and by a determined effort to forward the good work, show to the people of the country that the county of Henrico has not forgotten her duty.
I also call upon the citizens of this county to assist me in returning to duty deserters from the army, who are now at home skulking from their duty, while their follow soldiers are suffering from the cold and exposure of the winter.
To all such I would say, that I will make every endeavor to arrest them, and return them to their respective companies.
To those wishing to volunteer I would say, that I can be found over the store of Seldan & Miller, No. 15 Cary street, between the hours of 9 and 3 o'clock, every day.

div3.head: Important to conscripts.
div3.p:
--The undersigned having been detailed for a short time on recruiting service for the city of Richmond, would respectfully announce, by authority vested in me by order of Major-General G. W. Smith, the partial suspension of the conscript law, so as to permit conscripts to volunteer in the companies of their own selection in this command, without passing through camps of instruction, and receive the bounty and other benefits provided by law for volunteers.
I urge upon the people of this city the importance of speedily filling up the ranks of our army, in order that the threatened invasion of the State may be repelled.

It is confidently hoped that with the liberal inducements I am authorized to tender to conscripts, a large number will be added to the rolls, and ample means thereby secured for the common defence.
A candid and earnest appeal will be sufficient, it is believed, to awaken you to this high duty which you owe to yourselves and to your country.
I can be found at any time between the hours of 10 A. M. and 9 P. M. in the Military Hall, above the Old Market, corner of 17th and Main streets.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --In accordance with special Orders, No. 39, from the Adjutant, and Inspector-General's Office, I am now in Powhatan on recruiting service, and announce the partial suspension of the Conscript law, so as to permit conscripts to volunteer in the companies of their own selection, without passing through camps of instruction, and to receive the bounty and other benefits provided by law for volunteers.

It is useless for me to make an appeal to your patriotism.
The desolate condition of the fairest portion of your State speaks in stronger terms than anything I could say. Come forward, then, one and all, and volunteer at once, that the vile invader may be swept from the sacred soil of your native State.
Any one within the conscript age who will come forward and volunteer will have the privilege of attaching himself to any company he may select, and will be furnished with transportation to the company on application to me. He will also receive $50 bounty and all other benefits provided by law in such cases.

div3.head:
[Extract]
headquarters,
Richmond, February 7, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, no 27.

IV, Brig-General Winder, commanding Department of Henrico, is charged with the duty of granting Passports beyond, the lines of the Confederate army which will be given in such instances, and upon such conditions, as he may deem proper; subject however, to the discretion of the General in immediate command of the lines through which the applicant desires to pass.
div3.closer:
By command of Maj. Gen. G. W. Smith.
Samuel W. Melton,
Major and A. A. General. fe 9--2t*

div3.head:
Headq'rs Co "I" 59th Reg. Va. Vols,
Manchester, Feb. 10th, 1863.
div3.p:
Deserted.--The following named men are deserters from my company, now stationed in Manchester.
If they will come and report to me at once, they will only lose their pay; but if brought back under arrest, will be court-martialed and dealt with as the court may direct:
Geo. Martin, of Brunswick co;
Wm. Chapman, a substitute;
Henry Donahoe, a substitute;
John Henry, a substitute;
J. T. Sleten, a substitute from Pittsylvania;
W. G. Moore; Powhatan;
H. G. Birdsong, Dinwidfile'.
I will give $30 reward for the delivery of each of the above named men to me, in Manchester; or if put in Castle Thunder in Richmond, so that I can get them.
div3.closer:
F. S. Mosey, Capt.
Co. I. 59th Reg't Va. Vols. fe 11--2aw2w*

div3.head: One Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Deserted, on the march from Culpeper to Fredericksburg, Va, on or about the 20th of Nov'r, W. P. Brown, a substitute in Co. F, 41st Virginia reg't. Said Brown professes to be a Canadian by birth.
He is about 21 years of age; 5 feet 8 inches high; of delicate appearance; dark complexion, and dark hair.
He formerly resided in Richmond.
A reward of $100 will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of the above deserter.
div3.closer:
A. H. Portlook, Capt Co. F.
41st Va. reg't, camp near Fredericksburg, Va. fe 9--3t*

div3.head: Notice to conscripts.
div3.p: --The Medical Examining Board for the 3d Congressional District is now holding its session at the Camp of Instruction, near Richmond.
All persons of conscript age, who have been authorized to appear before this board for final examination, will report immediately.

closer.signed: John A. Coke, Capt and Enroll'g Officer

div3.head: By the Govenor of Virginia — a proclamation.

div4.p:
--Information having been received by the Executive that Richard, a slave, is charged with a violent and brutal assault upon Atwell P. Pitin.
In the county of King William, whereby the life of said Pitts is believed to be in imminent peril, and the said slave has find from justice and is now going at larges therefore I do hereby offer a reward of two Hundred Dollars to any person who shall arrest the said slave Richard and deliver him into the jail or said county of King William, if that jail be safe, and if not have him examined and committed to some other safe jail; and I do moreover require all officers of this Commonwealth civil and military, and request the people generally, to use their best exertions to procure the arrest of the said slave Richard, that he may be brought to justice.
Give uncoverly hand as Governor and under the less seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond this 3d day of Feb'y 1861.
div4.closer:
John Letcher.
By the Governor:
George W. Murford,
Sec'y of the Com'th.

div4.p:
Richard is a slender and delicate negro, about 5 feet 5 or 6 inches in height, 17 or 18 years old, usually red eyes; but may be most easily recognized by the mark of a large could on the side of his head, which mark is entirely destitute of hair.
He was wearing at the time of his escape a gray uniform coat and pants, and an old military cap bound with red. He was hired last year to John D. Quarles, of Richmond, but a caped from him in April, and attached himself, as he stoled, to the "Thomas Artillery," from Richmond, and was with our army near Fredericksburg until the close of 1862.
It is believed that he is now lurking in or near Richmond, or is by this time with the Army of the Rappahannock.

div4.head: Additional reward.
div4.p: In addition to the above reward for the apprehension of Richard, a private reward will be paid by P. H. & W. R. Aylett, of two Hundred Dollars.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--I am informed that my man, John, who sometimes calls himself Jno Baker, or Jno Ligon, at others calls himself Joe, was taken up recently from the army near Fredericksburg, where he was employed as a cook, and sent to some of the public or private jails in the city of Richmond.
Any information furnished me in the county of Powhatan, Jefferson Post Office, or to me at the American Hotel.
No. 44, until Friday at 12 o'clock, will be liberally rewarded.
John is 23 years old, about 5 feet 2 or 3 inches high black, has a scar on his right or left arm occasioned by a burn.
He left my residence in July last, and I presume he has been with the army until he was apprehended.
The information I have leads a most to a certainly that he is now in the city of Richmond in jail.

div3.head: One Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Friday, January 16, 1863, a negro man named Griffin.
The said slave is about 28 years of age; dark brown skin; five feet four or six inches high, and his left arm smaller than his right, having been broken when young.
Griffin was formerly owned by Robt Lowe, of Capel Hill N. C, who sold him to J. Monroe Carler, of Richmond Va., on the 6th of October, 1862.
I will give the above reward for the capture and return to me of said slave, or for his confinement in jail, so that I get him again.

div3.head: One Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from Wylticsburg, in Charlotte county, during the month of June, 1862, my man Dartlett.
For his apprehension and delivery to me, if taken up out of the State, I will pay the above reward; if captured within the State, and placed in jail so that I can got him, I will pay $30 Bartlett is about 20 years of age, of small stature, weighing, perhaps, 130 pounds; 5 feet 5 inches high, mahogany color, one upper tooth out in front low forehead, and dull countenance.
When last seen he was in the vicinity of Clarksville.

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p:
--From my residence, in Powhatan county, on the 27th January, a negro man named Jerry.
He is about 35 years old, 5 feet high, front teeth out, and not very black skin, had on when he left a pair of wooden (maple) button shoes, ironed with hoop iron in four different places on each shoe.
A suitable reward will be given for his apprehension and delivery to me, or his confinement in jail.
It is thought that he is on the James river, though he may be elsewhere.

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--From the undersigned, about ten days since, my negro boy George.
For his apprehension and delivery to Mr. Robert Lumikim a reward of $25 will be paid George is about 17 or 18 years old, of a dark brown color, tolerably stout built, small head and face, walks slowly and lazily; when spoken to replies slowly with a downcast look; had on, when he left dark clothes, much worn, and an old straw hat; usually wears a short, shaggy, black over-coat.
He lived the latter part of last year at Mr. H. J. Smith's near Fairfield, and was again hired there this year but ran off. He is probably secreted by some one in the city or may be at some of the camps near the city.
If caught beyond the county lines, and delivered here to Mr. Lumpkin, an additional reward of $25 will be paid.
div3.closer:
J. R. Allee.
Corner Main and 11th sts. fe 9--63teosw1t

div3.head: Seventy-five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--In offered for the apprehension and delivery of my slave William Henry, who disappeared from the fortifications, around Richmond shout the 10th of December.
Said slave is about 19 years of age, 5 feet high, thick set, thick of speech, gruff in manner of speaking, and generally clears his throat before beginning; has a peculiarly formed head, protuberance on the back of it, and eyes somewhat popped.
The above reward is offered for the apprehension and delivery of said slave to me in Danville, or lodged in the jail in Richmond so that I get him in possession.

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--$100 reward.--Ran away from "Wakefield," the farm in Hanover next adjoining Mr. Geo. W. Doswell's, on Monday, the 9th instant, a negro man named Jim. Said negro is of dark complexion, 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high, about 23 years old, and has a defect in his right eye. He was dressed in gray clothes, and had on either boots or wooden bottomed yellow shoes.
Before leaving he spoke of going to the Junction to get with our army, and I especially request quartermaster's and wagon masters on the lines of the Central or Fredericksburgs Railroads to keep a look-out for him. I will pay the above reward for his apprehension and delivery in the Jail at Hanover Court-House, so that I get him again; or to myself in Richmond.

closer.signed: Ex'r of Mrs. Judith Smith, dec'd.

div3.head:
Office city Gas Works,
January 28th, 1863.
div3.p:
Four Hundred Dollars reward.--Ranaway, from the City Gas Works, few negro men. Ro Hughes is about 6 feet high, dark skin and about 25 years old; E'or'd Henson 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, mulatto, and about 22 years old; Fearn, 5 feet 8 inches high, dark skin, and about 25 years old. Frank was formerly on the York River railroad.
Eeljah Camphall, 5 feet 10 inches high, dark skin, and about 23 years old. The above reward will be paid for the delivery of the four, or $100 for the delivery of either one, at the City Gas Works, Mockette.

div3.head: Runaway in jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the jail of Henrico county, as a runaway, a negro boy named Jim as the property of John Montgomery of the county of York, Va. The said boy is about 18 years old, 5 feet 7 inches high, with brown skin; had on when committed a full suit of gray Virginia clothing.
The owner of said boy is requested to come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take him away, or he will be draft with as the law directs.

closer.signed: Geo. D. Pleasants, S. H. C.

div3.head: Forty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, since July, 1862, a negro man named Willis belonging jointly to A. E. Miller, dec'd late of toway county, Va. The said negro is a bright mulatto, about 50 years of age, 5 feet 8 inches high, slightly bald, steps quick, and stoops a little when walking.
He was purchased of Mr. John Pride of Amella county, where he has a wife.
He is a good boot and shoemaker, and may be passing as a man. I will give the above reward if confined in any jail, where we can get him. Address Bimiller, or Or J. A. Agnew, executors of A. R. Miller's estate, Richmond.

div3.head: Two Hundred and fifty Dollars reward
div3.p:
--For my woman Vins, who escaped from the Bollingbrock Hotel, in Petersburg, the 12th January.
She had on a horsespun dress.
She is about 25 years old, dark skin.
She was hired to Mr. John Danutan, in Petersburg, in 1861.
I bought her from Mr. Alphens A. Rewistt, is Chesterfield.
She may be harbored by some person in or near Petersburg.
If so, I will give fifty dollars in addition to the above reward for their defection.
If caught she may be placed in jail in Petersburg or Richmond.
Address any information concerning her to H. A. Pearce, Richmond, Va. or Mr. Robert F. Jackson, at the office of the South-Side Railroad, Petersburg, Va.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on Monday last, a Negro Woman named Kitty, aged 40 years. Kitty is black, of medium height, rather stout, has lost a portion of her front teeth, and her eye teeth projects so as to be quite noticeable.
Kitty was originally from the neighborhood of Louisa Court House, and may be attempting to make her wet back.
She took with her several Linsey dress and other articles of wearing apparel.
I will give the above reward for her arrest and confinement in jail so that I get her again.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my residence on the night of the 25th January, my house boy George.
The said boy is a bright mulatto, 5 feet 8 inches high.
He had on when he left a gray coat, gray pants, shoes that had been smartly worn, and gray cap. He is 22 years old, with fine act of teeth and tall suit of black hair.--He has a little impediment in his speech when spoken to. He may be making his way to our army.
It caught in the county, I will pay $25; if caught out of the county and ridged in jail as that I get him again, I will pay $40.

closer.signed: Verdon P. O. Hanover county, Va.

div3.head: One Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Ran away from the subscriber on the 1st day of February, a dark brown skin negro man, 4 feet high, named Peter, about 23 years old. I will give the above reward to any person who will bring him to me, or have him confined in any jail in the State that I may got him. He has a wife in Powhatan county, and was recently bought in Scottland county, Va.
div3.closer:
Daniel F. Ward.
Falls Plantation, Chesterfield county, Va fe 3--2w

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--$25 reward — Ran off with the subscriber, in the city of Richmond, on the 27th last., a black Girl about 14 years old, not very good teeth in front.
She was purchased of Mrs. Mary W. Coleman, of Carolina county and may be making her way back.
I will pay $25 for her arrest and delivery to Hill, Dickinson & Co.
